description: From Middle English ketel, also chetel, from Old English Ä‹ietel (â€œkettle, cauldronâ€) and in Middle English possibly influenced by Old Norse ketill and both from Proto-Germanic *katilaz (â€œkettle, bucket, vesselâ€), of uncertain origin and formation. entries.meaning: A vessel for boiling a liquid or cooking food, usually metal and equipped with a lid.
examples: To cook pasta, you first need to put the kettle on.
There's a hot kettle of soup on the stove.

entries.meaning: The quantity held by a kettle.
A vessel or appliance used to boil water for the preparation of hot beverages and other foodstuffs.
examples: Stick the kettle on and we'll have a nice cup of tea.

entries.meaning: (geology) A kettle hole, sometimes any pothole.
(ornithology, collective) A group of raptors riding a thermal, especially when migrating.
An instance of kettling; a group of protesters or rioters confined in a limited area.

verbs.description: kettle (third-person singular simple present kettles, present participle kettling, simple past and past participle kettled)

entries.meaning: (Britain, of the police) To contain demonstrators in a confined area.
examples: [â€¦]  to contain demonstrators for hours in a confined spot. This tactic, known as kettling, is seen by some as an attempt to prevent people lawfully demonstrating.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) Of a boiler: to make a whistling sound like the boiling of a kettle, indicative of various types of fault.
Alternative form of kiddle (â€œkind of fishweirâ€)
